oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Killed in crash: air crash kills Cornelia Fort
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper article announcing Cornelia Fort's death in a plane crash on March 21, 1943. Although no details were known at the time this article was printed, the article does state that witnesses saw Fort's plane collide with another on the same ferrying mission over Texas. The article also includes a picture of Fort.

Cornelia Fort was the first female pilot in Nashville to earn her pilot's license. Before the United States entered World War II, she worked as flight instructor and was giving a lesson in Hawaii when she nearly collided with a Japanese plane headed for Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941. Shortly after, Fort returned to the United States and was the second woman to join the Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron (WAFS). She became the first woman to die in military service during WWII when her airplane collided with another aircraft during a ferrying mission.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: World War 1939-1945; Women and the military; United States-- Armed Forces--Women's Reserves; United States-- Armed Forces-- Women; World War 1939-1945-- Participation, Female-- Tennessee; World War 1939-1945-- War Work-- Tennessee
